G.L. c. 208, \u00a728.proposition: This Honorable Court has **continuing jurisdiction** over matters of custody and visitation concerning the minor child pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, §28, G.L. c. 209C, §20, and G.L. c. 215, §6**.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a720.proposition: This Honorable Court has **continuing jurisdiction** over matters of custody and visitation concerning the minor child pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, §28, G.L. c. 209C, §20, and G.L. c. 215, §6**.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a76.proposition: This Honorable Court has **continuing jurisdiction** over matters of custody and visitation concerning the minor child pursuant to **G.L. c. 208, §28, G.L. c. 209C, §20, and G.L. c. 215, §6**.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: These changes constitute a **material and substantial change in circumstances** affecting Emily’s welfare and justify modification of the prior custody order.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is a relocation/removal case under Mass. Gen. Laws c. 208, § 30 and applies a best-interests-of-the-child standard in the context of joint physical custody. It does not frame the relocation, school issues, or alleged abuse as a “material and substantial change in circumstances” justifying modification, nor does it discuss the threshold standard for modifying a prior custody order in those terms. The case therefore does not provide authority for the specific proposition that these changes constitute a material and substantial change warranting modification.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “The mother wishes to remove the children from the Commonwealth, and the father, who shares legal and physical custody with her, has refused to consent… General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that… [a child] shall not … be removed out of this Commonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders. ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’… We turn to the propriety of the judge’s order denying permission for the mother to remove the children.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: These changes constitute a **material and substantial change in circumstances** affecting Emily’s welfare and justify modification of the prior custody order.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion is a direct-appeal divorce/custody decision, not a post-judgment modification case. The court applies the ‘best interests of the child’ standard to an original custody determination and related visitation, and nowhere discusses or applies the “material and substantial change in circumstances” test that governs later modification of an existing custody order. Thus, it does not provide authority for the proposition that certain changes constitute a material and substantial change justifying modification of a prior custody order.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings, which are founded on the evidence.”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that when the circumstances relevant to a child’s welfare have changed, the Court must revisit custody in the child’s best interests.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/custody decision applying a best-interests analysis in the context of an initial divorce judgment, not a post-judgment modification based on changed circumstances. Nowhere does the court state that when circumstances relevant to a child’s welfare have changed the court must revisit custody; it simply applies the best-interests standard in making the original custody and removal determinations. Thus, it does not establish the consistent Massachusetts rule on modification upon changed circumstances that the proposition describes.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The judge was warranted in concluding that physical custody in the wife was in the best interests of each child… Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices… An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change… the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent….”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that when the circumstances relevant to a child’s welfare have changed, the Court must revisit custody in the child’s best interests.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion is about the standards and required findings in an initial custody determination in the context of domestic violence, and about remanding for more explicit findings. It does not discuss modification of an existing custody order based on changed circumstances, nor state that changed circumstances obligate a court to revisit custody in the child’s best interests. Massachusetts law does recognize that principle elsewhere, but this particular case is not about that issue and therefore does not provide authority for the proposition as framed.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: "Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above."

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that when the circumstances relevant to a child’s welfare have changed, the Court must revisit custody in the child’s best interests.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The case discusses the ‘best interests of the child’ standard for initial custody determinations under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) and explicitly declines to apply or analyze the ‘substantial change in circumstances’ standard governing modification under § 20. It does not address what happens when circumstances later change or whether a court must revisit custody upon such changed circumstances, nor does it describe any consistent Massachusetts practice on that point. The proposition about revisiting custody after changed circumstances is therefore not supported by this opinion.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20…. ”}

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: The court’s paramount consideration is the **best interests of the child**, informed by stability, parental fitness, and the quality of each parent–child relationship.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly identifies the governing standard as the child’s best interests once parental unfitness is established, and applies that standard by weighing stability, the child’s attachments, and the comparative ability of each prospective caregiver to meet the child’s needs. The court discusses the importance of stability and existing bonds, but upholds the trial judge’s decision to prioritize the child’s long‑term developmental welfare and the quality of the prospective parent–child relationship with the aunt, confirming that best interests—shaped by these factors—is the paramount consideration.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: "Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). … Stability in the life of a child, especially one as young as Hugo, is important, as the judge himself recognized. … Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development."

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The court’s paramount consideration is the **best interests of the child**, informed by stability, parental fitness, and the quality of each parent–child relationship.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames both custody modification and removal decisions in terms of the child’s best interests, and it evaluates those interests through factors of stability, parental fitness/quality of care, and the child’s relationships with each parent and extended family. The court emphasizes that a modification must be necessary for the child’s welfare, that uprooting a child requires compelling reasons, and that removal analysis looks to the child’s quality of life as intertwined with the custodial parent’s well‑being. This aligns with the proposition that the paramount consideration is the child’s best interests, informed by stability, parental fitness, and the quality of parent–child relationships.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ … ‘The uprooting of a child . . . should be done only for compelling reasons.’ … ‘Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…’”}

Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.proposition: In considering a modification, the Court may weigh the child’s expressed preferences when age and maturity warrant, especially where corroborated by evidence of emotional benefit.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.support_reasoning: The case is a care and protection proceeding determining initial (permanent) custody with the Department of Social Services, not a modification of an existing custody order. While the opinion notes that the older child expressed reluctance or unwillingness to visit his parents because of fear of his father, the court does not discuss any legal standard about weighing a child’s stated preference, nor frame its decision as turning on the child’s wishes or emotional benefit. Thus, it does not establish or affirm the proposition about considering a child’s preferences in modification proceedings.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610 (19.relevant_excerpt: "The judge found that the older child is aggressive and that this characteristic stems from fear. In addition, he found that the child did not view his environment as safe, could not control his impulses, and had a poor self-image. On several occasions, the judge found, the child had expressed either reluctance or unwillingness to visit his parents because of fear of his father. The judge adopted the opinion of the psychologist ... that the son needed an emotionally stable home environment unavailable to him in the home of his parents."

Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).proposition: In considering a modification, the Court may weigh the child’s expressed preferences when age and maturity warrant, especially where corroborated by evidence of emotional benefit.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).support_reasoning: The opinion is an alimony modification case between two ex‑spouses; the parties’ children are emancipated, and there is no discussion of custody, parenting time, or consideration of a child’s expressed preferences. The court focuses entirely on statutory alimony factors under G.L. c. 208, §§ 34 and 37, retirement, earning capacity, and retroactive modification, not on weighing a child’s wishes. Therefore, it does not support the proposition about considering a child’s preferences in modification proceedings.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).relevant_excerpt: "They have two children from their marriage, both of whom are emancipated. ... Discussion. 'To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.' Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981). Here, Rudolph was successful in modifying the divorce judgment with respect to his alimony obligation, but he did not succeed in terminating that obligation."

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: In considering a modification, the Court may weigh the child’s expressed preferences when age and maturity warrant, especially where corroborated by evidence of emotional benefit.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion applies the best-interests standard, discusses factors such as stability, parental alienation, work schedules, and sibling relationships, but it does not discuss or rely on the child’s own expressed custodial preferences or age/maturity. There is no analysis of the child’s stated wishes or of emotional benefit as corroborating those wishes. Because the court’s reasoning does not mention weighing the child’s preferences at all, the case does not support the specific proposition for which it is cited.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] . . . what is ‘best for the child’ . . . . However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”

Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.raw_text: Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981)
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.proposition: Where one parent’s circumstances have improved and permit greater stability and caretaking responsibility, modification expanding that parent’s parenting time promotes the best interests of the child.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.support_reasoning: The case concerns a custodial parent’s request to remove children to another state, not a modification expanding parenting time based on improved circumstances of the other parent. The court emphasizes that in removal decisions the best interests of the child are closely tied to the welfare of the custodial parent and criticizes a narrow focus on maintaining weekly visitation, but it does not hold that an improvement in the noncustodial parent’s circumstances justifies expanding that parent’s parenting time. The proposition mischaracterizes the subject and holding of Hale, which is about relocation standards, not increased parenting time for an improved parent.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.relevant_excerpt: “The best interests of children for purposes of deciding whether to permit removal are also interwoven with the well being of the custodial parent, and the determination, therefore, requires that the interests of the mother also be taken into account.… We conclude that while the trial judge considered one important factor, the children’s need for weekly visitation by the noncustodial parent, we cannot ascertain whether he also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests.”

Roe v. Roe, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 168 (1994).raw_text: Roe v. Roe, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 168 (1994)
Roe v. Roe, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 168 (1994).proposition: Where one parent’s circumstances have improved and permit greater stability and caretaking responsibility, modification expanding that parent’s parenting time promotes the best interests of the child.
Roe v. Roe, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 168 (1994).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether the Attorney General, representing the Commonwealth, may recover attorney’s fees as an “aggrieved person” under the Massachusetts anti-discrimination housing statute. It does not involve custody, parenting time, parental circumstances, or the best interests of a child. Accordingly, it cannot be authority for modification of parenting time based on changed parental circumstances or child’s best interests.
Roe v. Roe, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 168 (1994).relevant_excerpt: The principal issue on appeal from a Superior Court judgment adverse to the Dowds is whether the Commonwealth, in the person of the Attorney General, may recover, in the same manner as a private person might, reasonable legal fees on account of the Attorney General’s exertions in bringing a successful action to enforce § 4(7). We decide that the government may not recover such amounts and reverse so much of the judgment as awarded $9,080 to the Commonwealth on account of legal fees.
